column2: Preventive measures and treatments

- Plant disease-resistant cultivars such as Akane, Chehalis, Liberty, and Tydeman Red.
- Clean up fallen leaves in the fall to reduce overwintering spores.
- Apply nitrogen fertilizers to enhance leaf decomposition.
- Prune trees for better air circulation.
- Use fungicides like Captan, chlorothalonil, or myclobutanil when conditions are favorable for infection.

Prune infected Plant parts.
- Apply fungicides like myclobutanil or fenhexamid at the onset of symptoms.
- Ensure proper air circulation around plants to minimize humidity.

Plant resistant varieties.
- Remove cedar trees near apple orchards to reduce spore sources.
- Apply fungicides during the flowering period.

Rotate crops to prevent recurrence.

-Destroy infected leaves, berries and crop residues
-Protect pruning wounds with fungicides to minimize infection
-Use of an appropriate fungicide on pruning wounds can prevent the fungus from entering the plant
-Fungicide should be applied at time of pruning

Nutritional Management: Enhance tree nutrition through foliar sprays of readily absorbable nutrients and phytohormones to improve tree health and fruit quality.
Cultural Practices: Remove and destroy infected trees to prevent the spread of the disease. Ensure good orchard sanitation by eliminating potential sources of infection.
Insect Control: Implement intensive chemical control measures to manage the Asian citrus psyllid populations, which are responsible for spreading HLB.
Research and Development: Ongoing research is focused on developing resistant citrus varieties and exploring treatments that can alleviate symptoms, such as the use of antioxidants and growth hormones.
Monitoring and Reporting: Regularly inspect citrus trees for symptoms of HLB and report any findings to agricultural authorities to help control outbreaks.
